abstract.text: Results based on 106 M ψ ′ events and about 226 M J/ψ events acquired with the BESIII detector at BEPCII are reported, including a confirmation of the BESII pp threshold enhancement in J/ψ → γpp, branching ratios for χcJ → π 0 π 0 and ηη, and first measurements of the branching ratios for ψ ′ → π 0 hc and hc → γηc, as well as measurements of the mass and width of the hc. Also reported are first observations of the two photon process ψ ′ → γγJ/ψ and f0(980) − a0(980) mixing.

body_text.text: I. INTRODUCTION

The Beijing Electron-Positron Collider has been upgraded to a two-ring collider (BEPCII) with a design luminosity of 1 × 10 33 cm −2 s −1 at a center-of-mass energy of 3.78 GeV. It will operate between 2 and 4.6 GeV, allowing precision studies of charmonium (J/ψ, ψ ′ , ψ(3770), η c , χ cJ , and h c ), charm (D and D s mesons), and improved determinations of the tau mass and the hadronic cross section (R) in this energy region. Details on BESIII and BEPCII are described in Ref. [1].

During 2009, BESIII acquired a sample of 106 M ψ ′ events, or four times the CLEOc sample, and about 226 M J/ψ events, or about four times the BESII J/ψ sample. Results in this paper are based on these data sets.
II. hc STUDIES

In 2005, CLEO [2] reported a measurement of the mass of the h c ( 1 P 1 ) in e + e − → ψ ′ → π 0 h c , h c → γη c , where they used both inclusive and exclusive η c decay events. In 2008, they repeated their analysis with 25 M ψ ′ events. [3] Combining results, they obtain m(h c ) AV G = 3525.2 ± 0.18 ± 0.12 MeV/c 2 . [3] A precise determination of the mass is important to learn about the hyperfine (spin-spin) interaction of P wave states. Using the spin weighted centroid of the 3 P J states, < m( 3 P J ) >, to represent m( 3 P J ), they obtain ∆m hf (1P ) = < m( 3 P J ) > −m( 1 P 1 ) = +0.08±0.18±0.12 MeV/c 2 . This is consistent with the lowest order expectation of zero.

BESIII has measured m(h c ) from the distribution of mass recoiling against π 0 s, both in inclusive ψ ′ → π 0 h c samples and with samples tagged by the E1 photon from h c → γη c . This allows for the first time determinations of B(ψ ′ → π 0 h c ) and B(h c → γη c ). BESIII also measures for the first time the width Γ(h c ). Preliminary results are given in Table III and compared to CLEOc [12] and perturbative QCD predictions, [13] which for χ c1 → γV are an order of magnitude too low. BESIII observes χ cJ → γφ for the first time. BESIII has also fit the helicity angle distributions in the decays χ c1 → γV . The helicity angle is the angle between the V direction in the χ c1 rest frame and a daughter meson in the vector meson rest frame (ρ or φ) or the normal to the decay plane in the ω rest frame. N t is the number of fitted transversely polarized events, N l is the number of fitted longitudinally polarized events, and R is the ratio of the efficiencies for transversely and longitudinally polarized events, are given in   Two photon transitions are well known in excitations of molecules, atomic hydrogen, and positronium but except for the discrete transitions ψ ′ → γχ cJ , χ cJ → γJ/ψ have never been observed in charmonium systems. BESIII has searched for continuous two photon transitions using ψ ′ → γγJ/ψ, J/ψ → l + l − events, where l is e or µ. Selection requirements are used to reduce backgrounds from ψ ′ → γχ cJ , χ cJ → γJ/ψ and ψ ′ → π 0 J/ψ and ηJ/ψ. The invariant mass distributions of the two leptons for selected events are shown in Fig. 2. A clear excess is seen at the J/ψ peak over ψ ′ background from Monte Carlo simulation plus continuum background. Branching fractions of B(ψ ′ → γγJ/ψ) of (1.06 ± 0.08) × 10 −3 and (0.99 ± 0.07) × 10 −3 are determined for the J/ψ → ee and J/ψ → µµ cases, respectively. Combining, we determine B(ψ ′ → γγJ/ψ) = (1.02 ± 0.05 +0.19 −0.20 ) × 10 −3 . This is a first measurement. The result is preliminary, and more details can be found in Ref. The f 0 (980) and a 0 (980) are controversial particles. They have been described as qq or qqqq states, KK molecules, or qqG hybrid states. Mixing was first suggested by Achasov, [16] and mixing measurements may be important to clarify the nature of these particles. There have been suggestions [17] for BESIII to search for mixing signals in J/ψ → φf 0 → φa 0 → φηπ 0 , where the f 0 mixes to a 0 , and in the process [18] χ c1 → π 0 a 0 → π 0 f 0 → π + π − π 0 , where a 0 mixes to f 0 . The signal for the former case is shown in Fig. 3 a). The expected mixing signal is very narrow (8 MeV/ 2 ) between the K + K − and K 0 S K 0 S thresholds (987 -995 MeV/ 2 ). Backgrounds are sideband and a wide a 0 from J/ψ → γ * /K * K → φa 0 . Fitting to signal plus backgrounds determines 24.7 ± 8.6 mixing events or < 36.7 at the 90% confidence level (C.L.). This gives a mixing intensity ξ f a = (0.6 ± 0.2 ± 0.2)% or < 1.1% at the 90% C.L. For the latter mixing case, we determine ξ af = (0.32 ± 0.16 ± 0.12)% or < 0.91% at the 90% C.L. Figure 3 b) shows our results and upper limits compared to models (qq, q 2q2 , KK, and qqg) and calculated values (SND, KLOE, BNL, and CB) based on f 0 and a 0 parameters. References for models and calculations may be found in Refs. [17] and [18]. Ours are the first direct measurements. BESII observed a pp threshold enhancement in J/ψ → γpp. [19] Fitted to a S-wave resonance, it gives a mass below pp threshold of M (pp) = 1859 +3+5 −10−25 MeV/c 2 . BESIII has confirmed this observation [20] in ψ ′ → π + π − J/ψ, J/ψ → γpp with a fitted mass of M (pp) = 1861 +6+7 −13−26 MeV/c 2 and directly in J/ψ → γpp with a fitted mass of M (pp) = 1859±0.8 (preliminary and statistical error only), shown in Fig. 4 a). CLEOc also observes a pp threshold enhancement in ψ ′ → π + π − J/ψ, J/ψ → γpp and obtains a consistent fitted mass. [21] BESII also observed a resonance at M (η ′ π + π − ) = 1833.7±6.1±2.7 MeV/c 2 in J/ψ → γη ′ π + π − where η ′ → π + π − η and γρ. [22] BESIII also confirms this observation with a mass of M (η ′ π + π − ) = 1842.4±2.8 (preliminary and statistical error only), as shown in Fig. 4 b). Many results, many preliminary, have been presented based on BESIII samples of 106 M ψ ′ and about 226 J/ψ events. Many more results are to be expected in the future. In addition, BESIII acquired nearly 1f b −1 of data at the ψ(3770) resonance this year, including approximately 75pb −1 of scan data around the ψ(3770) peak. Decays of the ψ(3770) produce quantum correlated DD pairs, which are ideal for mixing and CP violation studies, as well measurements of absolute branching fractions and studies of semi-leptonic decays. This sample allows BESIII to begin their charm physics program.
